page.title: 02ALMONDS WOOD
page.content: COPPICED HAZEL IS PREDOMINANT AND ALMOST AS COMMON IS SILVER BIRCH. ALDERS ARE GROWING NEAR THE STREAM WHICH FLOWS THROUGH THE WOOD. IT IS SLOW, CONTAINING CLAY AND STONES, AND FAIRLY SHALLOW. MANY CHESTNUTS HAVE HONEY SUCKLE CLIMBING OVER THE TRUNKS. SOME ELDER AND THE OCCASIONAL ASH, OAK AND BEECH CAN BE SEEN. BRACKEN, FERN AND BLUEBELL SEED PODS ARE SCATTERED ON THE FLOOR AND THERE IS AN OCCASIONAL COMMON SPOTTED ORCHID. SPEEDWELL, YELLOW PIMPERNEL, STINGING NETTLE AND MOSSES ARE IN A GROUP TOGETHER NEAR THE MANY BURROWS OF THE RABBITS. ALSO NEARER THE STREAM IS GROUND ELDER. OTHER PLANTS ARE BUGLE, BUTTERCUP, DEAD NETTLE AND HAWTHORN. SCRAPED BARK ON THE GROUND GIVES EVIDENCE OF SQUIRRELS AND WE SEE LACE WING, SPIDERS, WOODLICE, BEETLES, BUTTERFLIES, FLIES AND SLUGS.
